Kolbe's picture of the year 32 is entirely different.  For Octavian to vacate at that moment so comprehensive an imperium as the triumviral would have been in his view an act of incredible folly.  Consequently,  whatever Octavian said later,  his power in 32 was triumviral ; and rations almost as strong must be held to have compelled him to carry on this triumviral power right down to 27.  We must presumably explain the Res Gestae by saying that in after years Octavian was more concerned with implicitly denying the imperium of his colleague than with asserting thing specific for himself.  Kolbe's point is that at the time other tions would have been paramount,  and that Octavian could not afford such a gesture in the consulate of Domitius and Sosius.  We can now recapitulate.  Of Kolbe's two propositions ( a ) that the triumvirate's terminal date had been fixed at end 32 and ( b ) that triumviral powers were continued after the terminal date,  either one could be sustained without the other,  ( a ) finds some support in what little we know about the plans made in 37,  and it is not impossible to explain away the apparently contradictory evidence of the Res Gestae^ though Schönbauer's attempt to do so is not entirely factory.  The second proposition ( b ),  whether it be applied to a terminal date at end 33 or to one at end 32,  has to face the fairly certain fact that from 32 onwards Octavian is not called »Illvir« in official designations.  »Posito triumviri nomine consulem se ferens«,  although Tacitus is hardly to be taken as an accurate researcher into this period 1®,  at least conforms with the extent titularies of the years following the beginning of the sulate of 31.  Yet even if Octavian discarded the name,  it would seem that men thought of the period which ended with the »settlement of 27 « as one in which the form of government was akin to the triumviraU^.  So much may be conceded to Kolbe,  but we must now look at the question whether any manifest substitute for the triumviral powers was in fact provided before the act of renunciation in the 6th and 7th consulates. 
There is of course no explicit evidence of the passage of a law or torial decree which granted a new imperium ( other than the consulate ) before 27.  The view that any such conferment was made involves attaching legal validity to other types of machinery.  This view is stated unambiguously by M.  Granti®.  In 32 the action of Italy gave Octavian an imperium to fight
